Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: High Temperature Thermometric Materials for Power Generation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to discover the commercial opportunity for high temperature thermoelectric materials and devices. A total of ~2600 trillion BTU/year of wasted heat energy are generated during US industrial processes, which can be directly converted into 16GWh of electricity using the outlined high temperature thermoelectric device. The value of this generated energy is estimated to be $14 billion/year using current electricity pricing, $0.10/KWh. During the course of this program the team will investigate the potential market to determine customer?s needs and the key requirements for a viable solution. Our customer discovery will begin with the target industry power generation. If this market offers limited potential, we will explore other potential markets, such as portable electronics and chemical processing, to explore their needs and requirements.

This I-Corps project uses structured hypothesis-validation approach to develop commercial translation plan of high temperature thermoelectric materials and devices. This will include determining: value proposition; customer/user-case; demand creation; channel development; revenue model; partnership strategy; and resource development. The fundamental knowledge to be used includes: 1) tuning the thermoelectric properties of nitrides and oxides through controlling nanostructure length-scale and 2) developing cost-effective materials processing technology for nanostructure thermoelectric materials. As a result, a market specific prototype of a non-toxic and cost effective thermoelectric device may be developed to enable large-scale waste heat harvesting in the high temperature regime.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF I-Corps team project is built upon the discovery and technology innovation on the nanostructured oxides and nitrides thermoelectric (TE) materials for high temperature power generations. The PI and her research team have filled multiple knowledge gaps in technology transition of the high temperature oxides thermoelectric materials, including value proposition; customer/user-case; demand creation; channel development; revenue model; partnership strategy; and resource development. The scientific contributions of this program included 1) conducted a systematic study of processing-structural-property relationship of high performance thermoelectric materials; 2) developed cost-effective manufacturing methods for large scale production of high performance thermoelectric generators. This program has enabled a commercial plan for using non-toxic thermoelectric materials for power generation in underground piping industry.

            High temperature thermoelectric oxides materials are suitable for energy harvesting where has continuous free heat source, such as power plant, industrial processing and piping in oil & gas industry. A total of ~2,567 trillion BTU/year of waste heat is generated from common industrial processes, such as power plant, metal furnaces and chemical production where the gas temperatures often exceed 1000K. This lost energy can be directly converted into ~ 6 to 16GWh of electricity using TE devices with 5% –20% conversion efficiency. Using the electricity price of $0.10/KWh as the baseline, the value of the energy generated from this TEG device is estimated at a total of $160 million/hour, approximately $14 billion/year. Due to the heat source being free, a large gross margin can be expected as long as the cost of TEG devices is competitive to other energy production technologies. The PI and her team has disclosed a patent application on a roll to roll manufacturing process to enable a low-cost thermoelectric devices. The team has also worked on a prototype development and deposition plan for bring the technology to markets.

             This program has provided training opportunities for the PI and two graduate students at the Purdue University to develop skillset in technology transfer. These skills could help the researchers commercializing their future inventions. The PI and her team also involve in providing research experience for four undergraduate students work as summer intern to study thermoelectric materials synthesis, characterization skillsets and device design modeling work. By collaborating the Duke Energy Academy at Purdue University, this program has engaged eight high school students in research experience for synthesis of thermoelectric materials and thermoelectric device fabrications.

            The research results have been disseminated to scientific communities through one peer-reviewed publication and one international conference presentation. The research team has also disseminated their I-Corps experience and “Lean LaunchPad method” to local and regional business community through multiple business venues, including Purdue Foundry, Purdue Research Foundations, Polsky Center Woman in STEM leadership conference etc.
